title: יִגְדַּל (אשכנז)‏ | Yigdal, by Daniel ben Yehudah Dayyan (abridged translation by Rev. Newton Mann, 1884)

coauthors.name: Newton Mann
coauthors.bio: Rev. Newton Mann (1836-1926), born in Cazenovia, New York, was a Unitarian minister in Wisconsin, New York, and Nebraska. At the outbreak of the Civil War he was appointed head of the Western Sanitary Commission, with which he served until the end of the war. He then entered the Unitarian ministry, and in 1865 organized the Unitarian Church in Kenosha, Wisconsin, where he was ordained and where he served for three years. Then followed a pastorate of two years in Troy, New York, and in 1870 he accepted a call to Rochester, where he remained eighteen years. His last charge was at Omaha, Nebraska, where for twenty years he ministered to a substantial congregation. He wrote Evolution of a Great Literature (1905), introducing scholarly biblical criticism to general readers.

coauthors.name: Max Landsberg
coauthors.bio: Max Landsberg (1845–1927), born in Berlin, Prussia, was the senior rabbi of the B'rith Kodesh Congregation, Rochester, New York, and one of the best known and most beloved Jewish religious leaders in the United States. He was the eldest son of the rabbi Meyer Landsberg (1810–1870) the rabbi of Hildesheim. After matriculating from high school in 1862, he studied philosophy and oriental philology at the universities of Göttingen and Breslau, completing his studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary of Breslau where he received his rabbinical degree. In 1866, he earned a doctorate from the University of Halle. From 1867, he taught at the seminary in Hanover until 1871 when, on the recommendation of the Jewish reformer Abraham Geiger (1810–1874), he moved to Rochester where he was elected rabbi of the B'rith Kodesh congregation, taking up his appointment in March 1871. In addition to his religious duties, thanks to his scholarship and his interest in philanthropy, he was soon recognized as one of the city's most eminent citizens. By 1894, under his leadership the B'rith Kodesh congregation had grown to more than 250. Langsberg was also active in supporting Rochester's charitable societies, aimed at improving conditions for the poor and needy. Under the United Hebrew Charities of Rochester, these included the Hebrew Benevolent Society, established in 1850, and the Hebrew Ladies' Benevolent Society (1865). He also contributed to social welfare and rights for immigrants, hosting events at the synagogue, including a presentation by the Danish-American social reformer Jacob Riis in 1901. Events were open to the public, in line with Landsberg's efforts to develop collaboration with Christian churches interested in similar objectives. For the JPS 1917 Tanakh, he translated the book of Genesis. He also published the Hymn book for Jewish worship (1880), Ritual for Jewish worship (1885), The position of woman among the Jews (1893), and Outline of the Jewish religion (1899).

excerpt: This is Rev. Newton Mann's rhymed English translation of Daniel ben Yehudah Dayyan's "Yigdal" as first published in Rabbi Max Landsberg's Ritual for Jewish Worship (1884), pp. 13-14. . . .
content:
Source (Hebrew) Translation (English)
יִגְדַּל אֱלֹהִים חַי וְיִשְׁתַּבַּח
נִמְצָא וְאֵין עֵת אֶל מְצִיאוּתוֹ׃
Extolléd be the living God and praiséd be his name,
Who was, and is, and is to be, eternally the same.
אֶחָד וְאֵין יָחִיד כְּיִחוּדוֹ
נֶעְלָם וְגַם אֵין סוֹף לְאַחְדּוּתוֹ׃
One God is he, no unity like his is there in aught;
A unity unending, Being beyond all thought.
אֵין לוֹ דְמוּת הַגּוּף וְאֵינוֹ גּוּף
לֹא נַעֲרֹךְ אֵלָיו קְדֻשָּׁתוֹ׃
Formless, all lovely forms but intimate his loveliness;
Holy, our holiest thoughts reveal him even less;
קַדְמוֹן לְכׇל־דָּבָר אֲשֶׁר נִבְרָא
רִאשׁוֹן וְאֵין רֵאשִׁית לְרֵאשִׁיתוֹ׃
Eternal, he was God ere aught was formed that now appears;
He is the First, and there was no beginning to his years.
הִנּוֹ אֲדוֹן עוֹלָם לְכׇל־נוֹצָר
יוֹרֶה גְּדֻלָּתוֹ וּמַלְכוּתוֹ׃
Lo! he is Lord of all the earth, Creation speaks his praise
And everywhere, above, below, his mighty will obeys.
שֶֽׁפַע נְבוּאָתוֹ נְתָנוֹ
אֶל אַנְשֵׁי סְגֻלָּתוֹ וְתִפְאַרְתּוֹ׃
His word by ancient prophets came to Israel, chosen face,
The first of whom was Moses, who beheld God face to face.
לֹא קָם בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל כְּמֹשֶׁה עוֹד נָבִיא
וּמַבִּיט אֶת־תְּמוּנָתוֹ׃‏
His word he gave his people by the prophet of his choice,
Whose faithfulness we celebrate with heart and soul and voice.
תּוֹרַת אֱמֶת נָתַן לְעַמּוֹ אֵל
עַל־יַד נְבִיאוֹ נֶאֱמַן בֵּיתוֹ׃
Established is his law, and changeless it must stand,
Written upon our human hearts and on the sea and land.
צוֹפֶה וְיוֹדֵעַ סְתָרֵֽינוּ
מַבִּיט לְסוֹף דָּבָר בְּקַדְמָתוֹ׃
He knoweth all our secret thoughts, naught from him is concealed,
The end from the beginning stands to him alone revealed.
גּוֹמֵל לְאִישׁ חֶֽסֶד כְּמִפְעָלוֹ
נוֹתֵן לְרָשָׁע רָע כְּרִשְׁעָתוֹ׃
יִשְׁלַח לְקֵץ יָמִים מְשִׁיחֵֽנוּ
לִפְדּוֹת מְחַכֵּי קֵץ יְשׁוּעָתוֹ׃
מֵתִים יְחַיֶּה אֵל בְּרֹב חַסְדּוֹ
בָּרוּךְ עֲדֵי־עַד שֵׁם תְּהִלָּתוֹ׃

This is Rev. Newton Mann’s slightly abridged rhymed English translation of Daniel ben Yehudah Dayyan’s “Yigdal” as first published in Rabbi Max Landsberg’s Ritual for Jewish Worship (1884), pp. 13-14. Mann, a Unitarian minister, had made the translation at the request of Rabbi Landsberg. Over at the Hymnology Archive, Chris Fenner writes,

When Max Landsberg (1845–1927), rabbi of the B’rith Kodesh Congregation in Rochester, New York, was assembling his Ritual of Jewish Worship (1884), he approached his friend Newton Mann, pastor of the Unity Church (Unitarian) in Rochester, about creating a version of the Yigdal in English rhyme. This appeared in the book, beginning “Extollèd be the living God and praisèd be his name,” in 9 rhyming couplets, effectively 8.6.8.6 (Common Meter). This text, unfortunately, did not have the same meter as the Hebrew and could not be used with existing Hebrew tunes. In his preface, Landsberg acknowledged Mann: “I cannot find adequate terms to express my obligations to my dear friend Rev. N.M. Mann, Pastor of Unity Church, for the kind interest he has taken in the preparation of Part First of this Ritual, and the valuable services he has rendered in making the English more idiomatic and perfect.”

Later on, at Rabbi Landsberg’s request, William Channing Gannet (Mann’s successor at Unity Church) revised Mann’s translation. That derived work was published in Unity Hymns and Chorals (1911). Many thanks to the Hymnology Archive and to Chris Fenner for his research.

I have set the text of Mann’s English translation side-by-side with the Hebrew source text of Yigdal indicating several of the verses left untranslated, likely a testament to the ideological differences of the Reform Judaism of Rabbi Landsberg. –Aharon Varady
